posts.name: Nicollas
posts.cooked: Hello, our team is currently uncertain about which sensor to use in a deployer. We would like to know which sensor model would be most appropriate for this application. We have tested several types, including infrared and ultrasonic, but we would like to know which would be the best for this case.

posts.name: Nick Aarestad
posts.cooked: Can you elaborate on what the function of a “deployer” is?

posts.name: Nicollas
posts.cooked:
outtake 1555×1080 215 KB It would actually be an outtake for corals. An example of it is exactly the one from SuperNurds, as shown in the image below.

outtake 1555×1080 215 KB

outtake 1555×1080 215 KB

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked: Well the SuperNurds look to be using this CANrange – CTR Electronics so that could be a good start.

posts.name: Nick Aarestad
posts.cooked:
Thank you! That helps a lot.

Lots of sensors can be used in this case. There really isn’t an overall “best” sensor for object detection like this, just a range of prices and characteristics.

We’ve historically used this style of generic photoelectric sensor , which works well enough.

Outside of that, there are solid options from Playing With Fusion , Banner/Andymark , REV or Adafruit that I’ve seen used successfully for this purpose. With Coral, you might even be able to do this well with a normal limit switch placed intelligently. I would take a look at the options, your packaging requirements, and your price range, and make a decision that optimizes for your particular needs.

Playing With Fusion - CAN Bus Time of Flight Range, Distance, and Proximity Smart Sensor

posts.cooked: Another option is a beam break type device. They can be purchased for a wide range of prices (don’t get the too cheap ones tho, as they don’t work consistently), and output into the DIO ports on the roboRIO. The ones we are using this year are https://www.mouser.com/ProductDetail/Banner-Engineering/QS18VN6LPQ7?qs=vvQtp7zwQdPuif%2FAL%2F0s3w%3D%3D with https://www.mouser.com/ProductDetail/Banner-Engineering/BRT-2X2?qs=vvQtp7zwQdM4dznIyVDM7g%3D%3D
haha you beat me to it. My team had a lot of issues with the adafruit ones last year, but they are also really cheap.

posts.name: Nick Aarestad
posts.cooked: Yeah, we’ve never used them, but I’ve heard from a few teams who made them work.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
The cheap beam break sensors don’t pull down low enough to actuate the RoboRio DIO ports.  An optocoupler or relay can fix this.

We’ve had annoying results with the KOP reflective sensors.  Especially when the kids change the component that is the far end from black to bare plastic.  Scream.

posts.name: Dan_Karol
posts.cooked:
These work great and are super inexpensive.  Only down side is you need to 3D print your own enclosure

Lidar-based distance sensors with simple digital interfaces for detection of nearby objects.  Options are available with maximum ranges of a few centimeters to a few meters.

We use the digital switch style.

You can see how we mounting it last year on our launcher here:
